en:
Subject pronoun 

 I, you, he(M)/she(F)/it(N), we, you, they
de:
Subjektpronomen (زوب یکت پرُنومن) 

 ich, du, er(M)/sie(F)/es(N), wir (ویِ), ihr (ایِ), sie-Sie

en: Where do the people come from?
He comes from Istanbul, and you?
de: Er kommt aus Istanbul, und du?

en: Complete the table with information from 4a (formal)
de: Ergänzen (اِرگن) Sie die Tabelle (تابِلِ) mit Informationen (این فرماتسیونِن) aus 4a

en: This is Dana. She is from Lublin. This is in Poland. She now lives in Germany
de: Das ist Dana. Sie ist aus Lublin. Das ist in Polen. Sie wohnt jetzt in Deutschland

en: This is Pablo. He comes from Spain, from Leon. He now lives in Munich
de: Das ist Pablo. Er kommt aus Spanien (اِشپانین), aus Leon. Er wohnt jetzt in München

desc:
"Welche" is used for feminine and plural nouns:

"Welche Blume magst du?" (Which flower do you like?)
"Welche Bücher liest du?" (Which books are you reading?)
"Welches" is used for neuter nouns:

"Welches Auto fährst du?" (Which car are you driving?)
"Welches Tier ist das?" (What animal is this?)

en:
Object pronoun - Akkusative 

 me, you, him(M)/her(F)/it(N), us, you, them
de:
Objektpronomen (آبیکت پرونومن) - Akkusative 

 mich, dich, ihn(M)(این)/sie(F)/es(N), uns (اونس), euch (اویچ), sie-Sie
desc: بی واسطه - چه چیزی را - چه کسی را

en:
Object pronoun - Dativ 

 me, you, him(M)/her(F)/it(N), us, you, them
de:
Objektpronomen (آبیکت پقونومن) - Dativ 

 mir (میِ), dir (دیِ), ihm(M)(ایم)/ihr(F)(اییِ)/ihm(N), uns (اونس), euch (اویچ), ihnen-Ihnen (اینن)
desc: با واسطه - به چه چیزی - به چه کسی

"Ihr" is a formal pronoun used when addressing someone with respect, especially in professional or formal situations. It is equivalent to the English "your" (formal) when addressing someone with respect

en: How do you write that, please?
Thank you Ms. Dumitru. Hope to see you
de: Danke schön, Frau Dumitru. Auf Wiedersehen

I speak a bit of German? English?

de: Namen (Eleni) und Nomen (Abend, Heft) schreibt man Groß (گُقُس)
desc: The word "man" is used in an impersonal sense, meaning "one" or "people" in English.

en: My husband, my son, my daughter and my wife
de: Mein Mann (/Mánn/), mein Sohn (/zoːn/), meine Tochter (تُختا) and meine Frau

desc:
"Das" can be translated to "this" when it refers to something nearby or within close proximity.
"Das" can be translated to "that" when it refers to something more distant or not immediately close.

Are you angry?

Bist du wütend? Nein,

en: How are you doing? (informal) Thank you, I'm doing well, and you?
de: Wie geht es dir (وی گِت اِس دیِ)? Dannke, es geht mir gut, und dir (دیِ)?
Wie geht es Ihnen? (وی گِت اِس اینِن)

desc:
In German, the verb "haben" (to have) is often used to express physical states and needs, such as hunger, thirst, or pain. So, when you say "Ich habe Hunger," you are literally saying "I have hunger" in English.

On the other hand, the phrase "Mir ist kalt" (literally, "to me is cold") is used to express sensations such as cold or warmth, rather than physical needs. This construction uses the dative case, which is used to indicate the indirect object of a sentence. In this case, "mir" (to me) is the indirect object, and "kalt" (cold) is the subject of the sentence.
"Ich habe" is the correct and standard form of "I have" in German. However, in spoken language or informal writing, it's common to use the contracted form "Ich hab" instead of "Ich habe".

en: Do you speak Portuguese? No, I speak Spanish. I am spanish
de: Sprichst (اشپریشْسْت) du Portugiesisch? (پُرتوگیزیش) Nein, ich spreche Spanisch (اشپانیش). Ich bin Spanier (اشپانیا)

desc:
Bär = bear 
 läuft = run 
 im = in the 
 Wald = forest

en: Is Vienna big, beautiful and cool?
de: Ist Wien (وین) groß (گُقُس), schön und cool?

desc: In German, the word "klein" (small) is an adjective that modifies the noun "Hund" (dog). Adjectives in German change their form based on the gender, number, and case of the noun they are describing. In this case, "Hund" is a masculine noun, so the correct form of the adjective is "kleiner" to match the gender and case

en: I would like to call the waiter please
de: Ich möchte bitte den Kellner (کِلنا) rufen (قوفِن)
desc:
Kellner = Waiter 
 rufen = call 
 In German, adverbs like "bitte" (please) typically come before the verb, so it should be placed before "den Kellner rufen.
